question:
Question 1 Let p and q be real numbers such that [latex]p^{2}+q^{2}=1[/latex]. The eigenvalues of the matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} p & q\\ q& -p \end{bmatrix}[/latex]
are
solution: Characteristic equation of A [latex] \begin{aligned} \left|A_{2 \times 2}-\lambda I\right|&=(-1)^{2} \lambda^{2}+(-1)^{1} \text{Tr}(A) \lambda+|A|=0 \\ \lambda^{2}-(p-p) \lambda+\left(-p^{2}-q^{2}\right) &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad\lambda^{2}-1 &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad \lambda &=\pm 1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 2 Let [latex]p\left ( z\right )=z^{3}+\left ( 1+j \right )z^{2}+\left ( 2+j \right )z+3[/latex], where z is a complex number. Which one of the following is true?
solution: Since sum of the roots is a complex number [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] absent one root is complex So all the roots cannot be real.

options.A: [latex]\text{conjugate}\:\left \{ p\left ( z \right ) \right \}=p\left ( \text{conjugate} \left \{ z \right \} \right )[/latex] for all z
options.B: The sum of the roots of [latex]p\left ( z \right )=0[/latex] is a real number
options.C:
The complex roots of the equation  [latex]p\left ( z \right )=0[/latex]
 come in conjugate pairs
options.D: All the roots cannot be real

question:
Question 3 Let [latex]f\left ( x \right )[/latex]
 be a real-valued function such that [latex]{f}'\left ( x_{0} \right )=0[/latex]
 for some [latex]x _{0} \in\left ( 0,1 \right )[/latex], and [latex]{f}''\left ( x \right )> 0[/latex]
 for all [latex]x \in \left ( 0,1 \right )[/latex]. Then [latex]f\left ( x \right )[/latex]
 has
solution: [latex]x_{0} \in(0,1)[/latex], where [latex]f(x)=0[/latex] is stationary point and [latex]f^{\prime \prime}(x)>0 \qquad \qquad \forall x \in(0,1)[/latex] So [latex]\qquad \qquad f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=0[/latex] and [latex]\qquad \qquad f^{\prime}(0)>0, \text { where } x_{0} \in(0,1)[/latex] Hence, f(x) has exactly one local minima in [latex](0,1)[/latex]

question: Question 4 For the network shown, the equivalent Thevenin voltage and Thevenin impedance as seen across terminals 'ab' is
solution: Given circuit can be resolved as shown below, [latex] V_{T H}=15+50=65 \mathrm{~V}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{x} &=2+3+10=15 \mathrm{~V} \\ R_{\mathrm{TH}} &=\frac{V_{x}}{1}=15 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 5 Which one of the following vector functions represents a magnetic field [latex]\overrightarrow{B}[/latex]? ([latex]\hat{X}[/latex], [latex]\hat{Y}[/latex]
 and [latex]\hat{Z}[/latex]
 are unit vectors along x-axis, y-axis, and z-axis, respectively)
Question 6 If the input x(t) and output y(t) of a system are related as [latex]y\left ( t \right )=\text{max}\left ( 0,x\left ( t \right ) \right )[/latex], then the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t) &=\max (0, x(t)) \\ &=\left\{\begin{array}{cl} 0, & x(t) \lt 0 \\ x(t), & x(t)\gt 0 \end{array}\right. \end{aligned}[/latex] Linearity check: at input [latex]x_{1}(t)=-2[/latex], output [latex]y_{1}(t)=0 [/latex] at input [latex]x_{2}(t)=1[/latex], output [latex]y_{2}(t)=1 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] system is non-linear because it violates law of additivity. Check for time-invariance : Delayed [latex]\mathrm{O} / \mathrm{P}:[/latex] [latex] y\left(t-t_{0}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl} x\left(t-t_{0}\right), & x\left(t-t_{0}\right) \gt  0 \\ 0 & x\left(t-t_{0}\right)\lt 0 \end{array}\right.[/latex] [latex] \mathrm{O} / \mathrm{P}[/latex] of system when input is [latex]x\left(t-t_{0}\right)=f(t)[/latex] [latex] y_{1}(t)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl} f(t), & f(t) \gt 0 \\ 0, & f(t)\lt 0 \end{array}=\left\{\begin{array}{cl} x\left(t-t_{0}\right), & x\left(t-t_{0}\right)\gt  0 \\ 0, & x\left(t-t_{0}\right)\lt 0 \end{array}\right.\right.[/latex] Therefore, system is time-invariant.

question: Question 7 Two discrete-time linear time-invariant systems with impulse responses [latex]h_{1}\left [ n \right ]=\delta \left [ n-1 \right ]+\delta \left [ n+1 \right ][/latex] and [latex]h_{2}\left [ n \right ]=\delta \left [ n\right ]+\delta \left [ n-1 \right ][/latex] are connected in cascade, where [latex]\delta \left [ n\right ][/latex] is the Kronecker delta. The impulse response of the cascaded system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(n) &=\text { Resultant impulse response } \\ &=h_{1}(n) * h_{2}(n) \end{aligned}[/latex] By applying z -transform [latex] \begin{aligned} H(z) &=H_{1}(z) \cdot H_{2}(z) \\ &=\left(z+z^{-1}\right)\left(1+z^{-1}\right) \\ &=z+Z^{-1}+1+z^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] By applying inverse ZT, [latex] h(n)=\delta(n+1)+\delta(n-1)+\delta(n)+\delta(n-2)[/latex]

question: Question 8 Consider the table given: [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Constructional feature} & \text{Machine type} & \text{Mitigation} \\ \hline \text{P. Damper bars} & \text{S. Induction motor} & \text{X. Hunting} \\ \hline \text{Q. Skewed rotor slots} & \text{T. Transformer} & \text{Y. Magnetic locking} \\ \hline \text{R. Compensating winding} & \text{U. Synchronous machine} & \text{Z. Armature reaction} \\ \hline \text{} & \text{V. DC machine} & \text{} \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex] The correct combination that relates the constructional feature, machine type and mitigation is
solution: P: Damper bars used in synchronous machine (U) to prevent hunting (X) Q: Skewed rotor slots used in induction motor (S) t avoid magnetic locking (Y) R: Compensating winding used in DC machine (V) to neutralize cross magnetizing effects of armature reaction (Z) under main poles (polar zone).

question: Question 9 Consider a power system consisting of N number of buses. Buses in this power system are categorized into slack bus, PV buses and PQ buses for load flow study. The number of PQ buses is [latex]N_{L}[/latex]. The balanced Newton-Raphson method is used to carry out load flow study in polar form. [latex]\text{H, S, M, and R}[/latex] are sub-matrices of the Jacobian matrix J as shown below: [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \Delta P\\ \Delta Q \end{bmatrix}=J\begin{bmatrix} \Delta \delta \\ \Delta V \end{bmatrix}, \text{where}\: J=\begin{bmatrix} H & S\\ M &R \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The dimension of the sub-matrix M is
solution: [latex]\left[\begin{array}{l} \Delta P \\ \Delta Q \end{array}\right]=J\left[\begin{array}{l} \Delta \delta \\ \Delta V \end{array}\right] \text { where } J=\left[\begin{array}{ll} H & S \\ M & R \end{array}\right][/latex] For size of M Row = No. of unknown variables of [latex]Q=N_{L}[/latex] Column = No. of variable which has [latex]\delta=N_{L}+\left(N-1-N_{L}\right) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=N-1\\ \text{So}, \quad\text{ size of }M&=N_{L} \times(N-1) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 10 Two generators have cost functions [latex]F_{1}[/latex] and [latex]F_{2}[/latex]. Their incremental-cost characteristics are [latex]\dfrac{dF_{1}}{dP_{1}}=40+0.2P_{1}[/latex] [latex]\dfrac{dF_{2}}{dP_{2}}=32+0.4P_{2}[/latex] They need to deliver a combined load of [latex]260 \text{~MW}[/latex]. Ignoring the network losses, for economic operation, the generations [latex]P_{1}[/latex]
 and [latex]P_{2}[/latex] (in [latex]\text{MW}[/latex]) are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I C_{1} &=I C_{2} \\ 40+0.2 P_{1} &=32+0.4 P_{2} \\ 0.4 P_{2}-0.2 P_{1} &=8 \\ P_{2}+P_{1} &=260 \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii), [latex] P_{1}=160 \mathrm{MW} ; P_{2}=100 \mathrm{MW}[/latex]

question: Question 11 For the closed-loop system shown, the transfer function [latex]\dfrac{E\left ( s \right )}{R\left ( s \right )}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{E(s)}{R(s)} &=\frac{R(s)-H \times C(s)}{R(s)}=1-H \times \frac{C(s)}{R(s)} \\ &=1-\frac{H G}{1+G H}=\frac{1+G H-G H}{1+G H} \\ &=\frac{1}{1+G H} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 12 Inductance is measured by
solution: Maxwell's bridge is used for measurement of inductance. Wein's bridge is used for measurement of frequency Kelvin's bridge is used for measurement of low value of resistance. Schering bridge is used for measurement of capacitance, dilectric loss and permittivity etc.

question: Question 13 Suppose the circles [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}=1[/latex] and [latex]\left ( x-1\right )^{2}+\left ( y-1 \right )^{2}=r^{2}[/latex] intersect each other orthogonally at the point [latex]\left ( u,v \right )[/latex]. Then  [latex]u+v=[/latex] _______________.
solution: If two curves cut orthogonally then product of slopes [latex]= -1[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} x^{2}+y^{2} &=1 \\ 2 x+2 y \frac{d y}{d x} &=0 \\ \left(M_{1}\right)_{u, v} &=\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{-x}{y}=\frac{-u}{v} \\ (x-1)^{2}+(y-1)^{2} &=r^{2} \\ \left(M_{2}\right)_{u, v} &=\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)=\left(\frac{-2(x-1)}{2(y-1)}\right)_{(u . v)}=\frac{1-u}{v-1} \\ \because \qquad \qquad M_{1} M_{2} &=-1\\ \frac{-u}{v} \times \frac{1-u}{v-1}&=-1\\ -u+u^{2} &=-v^{2}+v \\ u^{2}+v^{2} &=v+u \\ \because \qquad \qquad x^{2}+y^{2} &=1 \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad u+v &=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 14 In the given circuit, the value of capacitor C that makes current [latex]I=0[/latex]
 is _________ [latex]\mu F[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{L} &=(j 5) \|\left(j 5-j X_{c}\right) \\ \frac{(j 5)\left(j 5-j X_{c}\right)}{j 5+j 5-j X_{c}} &=\infty \\ j 5+j-j X_{c} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \qquad j X_{c} &=j 10 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \qquad X_{c} &=10 \Omega \\ X_{c} &=\frac{1}{\omega C}=10 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \qquad C&=\frac{1}{10 \times 5 \times 10^{3}} \\ C &=\frac{1}{5 \times 10^{4}} \times \frac{10^{2}}{10^{2}}=\frac{10^{2}}{5 \times 10^{6}}=20 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 Two single-core power cables have total conductor resistances of [latex]0.7\;\Omega[/latex] and [latex]0.5\;\Omega[/latex], respectively, and their insulation resistances (between core and sheath) are [latex]600\;M\Omega[/latex] and [latex]900\;M\Omega[/latex], respectively. When the two cables are joined in series, the ratio of insulation resistance to conductor resistance is ___________[latex]\times 10^{6}[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left(R_{\text {eq }}\right)_{\text {conductor }} &=0.7+0.5=1.2 \Omega \\ \left(R_{\text {eq }}\right)_{\text {in }} &=\frac{1}{\left(R_{e q}\right)_{\text {in }}}=\frac{1}{\left(R_{\text {in }}\right)_{1}}+\frac{1}{\left(R_{\text {in }}\right)_{2}}=\frac{1}{900 \times 10^{6}}+\frac{1}{600 \times 10^{6}} \\ \left(R_{\mathrm{eq}}\right)_{\text {in }} &=360 \times 10^{6} \Omega\\ \frac{\left(R_{\text {eq }}\right)_{\text {in }}}{\left(R_{\text {eq }}\right)_{\text {conductor }}}&=\frac{360 \times 10^{6}}{1.2}=300 \times 10^{6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 16 In the given circuit, for voltage [latex]V_y[/latex] to be zero, the value of [latex]\beta[/latex] should be _________. (Round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_{x}-6}{1}+\frac{V_{x}}{4}+\frac{V_{x}-V_{y}}{2} & =0 \\ 4 V_{x}-24+V_{x}+2 V_{x}-2 V_{y} & =0 \\ 7 V_{x}-2 V_{y} & =24 \\ \text { If } V_{y}=0 \qquad\qquad 7 V_{x} & =24 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad\qquad V_{x} & =\frac{24}{7} \\ \Rightarrow\qquad\qquad \frac{V_{y}-V_{x}}{2}+\frac{V_{y}-\beta V_{x}}{3} & =2 \\ 3 V_{y}-3 V_{x}+2 V_{y}-2 \beta V_{x} & =12 \\ 5 V_{y}-(3+2 \beta) V_{x} & =12 \\ V_{y} & =0\\ -(3+2 \beta) \frac{24}{7} &=12 \\ (3+2 \beta) &=\frac{-7}{2} \\ 2 \beta &=\frac{-7}{2}-3=\frac{-7-6}{2}=\frac{-13}{2} \\ \beta &=\frac{-13}{4}=-3.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 17 A [latex]1\;\mu C[/latex] point charge is held at the origin of a cartesian coordinate system. If a second point charge of [latex]10\;\mu C[/latex] is moved from [latex]\left ( 0,10,0 \right )[/latex] to [latex]\left ( 5,5,5\right )[/latex] and subsequently to [latex]\left ( 5,0,0\right )[/latex], then the total work done is ___________[latex]\text{mJ}[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places). Take [latex]\dfrac{1}{4\pi \varepsilon _{0}}=9\times 10^{9}[/latex] in SI units. All coordinates are in meters.
solution:
In this case work done is independent of type of path but depends an intial and final point. [latex]
\begin{array}{ccccccccc}
x & y & z & & r & \theta & \phi \\
(0, & 10, & 0) & \rightarrow & (10, & 90^{\circ}, & \left.90^{\circ}\right) & \text { Initial point }\\
x & y & z & & r & \theta & \phi & \\
(5, & 5, & 5) & \rightarrow & (5 \sqrt{3}, & 54.73^{\circ}, & \left.45^{\circ}\right) &  \text { Intermediate point } \\
x & y & z & & r & \theta & \phi & \\
(5, & 0, & 0) & \rightarrow & (5, & 90^{\circ}, & \left.0^{\circ}\right) &  \text { Final point }
\end{array}[/latex] Work done (by external source) in moving Q-charge ([latex]10 \mu C[/latex]) in the presence of electric field [latex]\vec{E}[/latex] is [latex]\begin{aligned} W&=-Q \int_{\text {initial point }}^{\text {final point }} \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{l}=-\left(10 \times 10^{-6}\right) \int_{r=10}^{r=5} \frac{9 \times 10^{3}}{r^{2}} \hat{a}_{r} \cdot d r \hat{a}_{r} \\ W&=-10 \times 10^{-6}\left(9 \times 10^{3}\right)\left(-\frac{1}{r}\right)_{r=10}^{5} \\ &=9 \times 10^{-2}\left[\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{10}\right]=9 \times 10^{-2}\left[\frac{10-5}{50}\right]=9 \times 10^{-2}\left(10^{-1}\right) \\ W&=9 \mathrm{~mJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 18 The power input to a [latex]\text{500 V, 50 Hz, 6-pole, 3-phase}[/latex]
 induction motor running at [latex]975 \text{ RPM}[/latex]
 is [latex]40 \text{ kW}[/latex] . The total stator losses are [latex]1 \text{ kW}[/latex]. If the total friction and windage losses are [latex]2.025\text{~ kW}[/latex], then the efficiency is _____________%.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{i / p} &=40 \mathrm{~kW}, \quad \text { stator loss }=1 \mathrm{~kW}, \quad \mathrm{~F} \text { and } W=2.025 \mathrm{~kW} \\ \text { Stator } \mathrm{o} / \mathrm{p} &=40-1=39 \mathrm{~kW} \\ \qquad \text { Slip } &=\frac{1000-975}{1000}=0.025 \\ \text { Rotor } \mathrm{o} / \mathrm{p} &=\text { Rotor } \mathrm{i} / \mathrm{p} \times(1-\mathrm{s}) \\ &=39(1-0.025)=38.025 \mathrm{~kW} \\ \text { Motor } \mathrm{o} / \mathrm{p} &=38.025-2.025=36 \mathrm{~kW}\\ \eta&=\frac{\text { Motor output }}{\text { Motor input }}=\frac{36}{40} \times 100=90 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 19 An alternator with internal voltage of [latex]1\angle \delta _{1}\text{p.u}[/latex]
 and synchronous reactance of [latex]\text{0.4 p.u}[/latex] is connected by a transmission line of reactance [latex]\text{0.1 p.u}[/latex] to a synchronous motor having synchronous reactance [latex]\text{0.35 p.u}[/latex] and internal voltage of [latex]0.85\angle \delta _{2}\text{p.u}[/latex]. If the real power supplied by the alternator is [latex]\text{0.866 p.u}[/latex], then [latex]\left( \delta _{1} -\delta _{2}\right)[/latex] is _________ degrees. (Round off to 2 decimal places.) (Machines are of non-salient type. Neglect resistances.)
solution: Given real power in (p.u.), [latex]P=0.866[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\frac{E V \sin \left(\delta_{1}-\delta_{2}\right)}{X_{\mathrm{eq}}}=\left|\frac{1 \times 0.85}{0.4+0.1+0.35}\right| \sin \left(\delta_{1}-\delta_{2}\right) \\ \left(\delta_{1}-\delta_{2}\right) &=60^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 The Bode magnitude plot for the transfer function [latex]\frac{V_{o}\left ( s \right )}{V_{i}\left ( s \right )}[/latex] of the circuit is as shown. The value of R is _____________[latex]\Omega[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: From response plot [latex] \begin{aligned} M_{r} &=26 \mathrm{~dB}=20 \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \frac{1}{2 \xi \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}} &=20 \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \xi &=0.025 \end{aligned}[/latex] From electrical network [latex] \begin{aligned} \chi&=\frac{R}{2} \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}}=0.025 \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad R&=0.10 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 21 A signal generator having a source resistance of [latex]50\:\Omega[/latex] is set to generate a [latex]\text{1 kHz}[/latex] sinewave. Open circuit terminal voltage is [latex]\text{10 V}[/latex] peak-to-peak. Connecting a capacitor across the terminals reduces the voltage to [latex]\text{8 V}[/latex] peak-to-peak. The value of this capacitor is _____________[latex]\mu F[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_{0}(j \omega)}{V_{i}(j \omega)} &=\frac{1}{1+j \omega R C} \\ \frac{8}{10} \angle \theta &=\frac{1}{1+j \omega R C} \\ 1+j \omega R C &=1.25 \angle \theta \\ \omega R C &=\sqrt{1.25^{2}-1^{2}} \\ \omega R C &=0.75 \\ C &=\frac{0.75}{2000 \pi \times 50}=2.38 \mu\mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 22 A 16-bit synchronous binary up-counter is clocked with a frequency [latex]f_{\text{CLK}}[/latex].The two most significant bits are [latex]\text{OR-ed}[/latex] together to form an output Y. Measurements show that Y is periodic, and the duration for which Y remains high in each period is [latex]\text{24 ms}[/latex]. The clock frequency [latex]f_{\text{CLK}}[/latex] is ___________[latex]\text{MHz}[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]y = 1[/latex] for 24 m sec [latex] \begin{array}{llcccc} & & Q_{15} & Q_{14} & \ldots \ldots & Q_{0} \\ y=1 & \text { Starts at } & 0100 & 0000 & 0000 & 0000 \\ y=1 & \text { Ends at } & 1111 & 1111 & 1111 & 1111 \end{array}[/latex] Total number of states for which [latex]y=1[/latex] is [latex]2^{16}-2^{14}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Time is }\left(2^{16}-2^{14}\right) T &=24 \mathrm{msec} \\ f &=\frac{1}{T}=2.05 \mathrm{MHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 In the [latex]\text{BJT}[/latex]
 circuit shown, beta of the [latex]\text{PNP}[/latex]
 transistor is 100. Assume [latex]V_{\text{BE}}=-0.7\;V[/latex]. The voltage across [latex]R_{c}[/latex]
 will be [latex]\text{5 V}[/latex]
 when [latex]R_{2}[/latex]
 is __________ [latex]k \Omega[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{C}&=\frac{5 \mathrm{~V}}{3.3 \mathrm{k}}=1.515 \mathrm{~mA} \\ I_{E}&=1.53 \mathrm{~mA} \\ I_{B}&=0.0151 \mathrm{~mA}\\ -12+1.2 \mathrm{k} \times 1.53 \mathrm{~m}+& 0.7+V_{B}=0 \\ V_{B} &=9.464 \mathrm{~V} \\ I_{x} &=\frac{12-V_{B}}{4.7 \mathrm{k}}=\frac{12-9.464}{4.7 \mathrm{k}}=0.539 \mathrm{~mA} \\ I_{x}+I_{B} &=I_{y} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad I_{y} &=0.5396+0.0151 \\ I_{y} &=0.5546 \mathrm{~mA} \\ V_{B} &=0.5546 \mathrm{~m} \times R_{2}=9.464 \\ R_{2} &=17.06 \mathrm{k} \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 In the circuit shown, the input [latex]V_{i}[/latex] is a  sinusoidal [latex]\text{AC}[/latex] voltage having an [latex]\text{RMS}[/latex] value of [latex]230\;V\pm 20\%[/latex]. The worst-case peak-inverse voltage seen across any diode is ____________V. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left(V_{D}\right)_{\text {peak }} \text { for worst case } &=(230+20 \%) \times \sqrt{2} \\ &=\left(230+230 \times \frac{20}{100}\right) \times \sqrt{2}=390.32 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 25 In the circuit shown, a [latex]\text{5 V}[/latex] Zener diode is used to regulate the voltage across load [latex]R_{0}[/latex]. The input is an unregulated DC voltage with a minimum value of [latex]\text{6 V}[/latex] and a maximum value of [latex]\text{8 V}[/latex]. The value of [latex]R_{S}[/latex]
 is [latex]6\;\Omega[/latex]. The Zener diode has a maximum rated power dissipation of [latex]\text{2.5 W}[/latex]. Assuming the Zener diode to be ideal, the minimum value of [latex]R_{0}[/latex] is _________________ [latex]\Omega[/latex].
solution: To calculate [latex]R_{0}[/latex] min' we must find [latex]I_{L}[/latex] max [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{s \min } &=I_{z} \min +I_{L \max } \\ \frac{V_{i \min }-V_{z}}{R_{s}} &=I_{z} \min +I_{L \max } \end{aligned}[/latex] For ideal zener diode, [latex]I_{z \min }=0[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{i \min }-V_{z}}{R_{s}} &=I_{L \max } \\ \frac{6-5}{6} &=I_{L \max } \\ I_{L} \max &=\frac{1}{6} \mathrm{~A} \\ R_{0} \min &=\frac{V_{z}}{I_{L \max }}=\frac{5}{1 / 6}=30 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 In the open interval [latex]\left ( 0,1 \right )[/latex], the polynomial [latex]p\left ( x \right) =x^{4}-4x^{3}+2[/latex] has
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x^{4}+2 &=4 x^{3} \\ f_{1}(x) &=x^{4}+2 \\ f_{2}(x) &=4 x^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] It is clear that point of intersection of these graphs is solution (or) root of [latex]p(x) = 0[/latex] According to intermediate value theorem [latex] P(0)[/latex] and [latex]P(1)[/latex] are having opposite signs [latex] \therefore [/latex] a root of [latex]p(x) = 0[/latex] in [latex](0, 1)[/latex] and also from graph, there is only one point of intersection Hence exactly one real root exists in [latex](0, 1)[/latex]

question:
Question 27 Suppose the probability that a coin toss shows "head" is p, where [latex]0\lt 
 p\lt 1[/latex]. The coin is tossed repeatedly until the first "head" appears. The expected number of tosses required is
solution: [latex]F(H) = p[/latex], let x = Number of tosses [latex] \begin{aligned} &\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline x & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 \ldots \\ \hline P(x) & p & (1-p) p & (1-p)^{2} p & & \\ \hline \end{array}\\ &\begin{aligned} E(x) &=\sum x_{i} P(x)=p+2(1-p) p+3(p)(1-p)^{2}+\ldots \\ &=p\left[1+2(1-p)+3(1-p)^{2}+\ldots\right] \\ &=p[1-(1-p)]^{-2}=\frac{1}{p} \end{aligned} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 28 Let [latex]\left ( -1 -j \right ), \left ( 3 -j \right ), \left ( 3 + j \right )[/latex]
 and [latex]\left ( -1+ j \right )[/latex] be the vertices of a rectangle C in the complex plane. Assuming that C is traversed in counter-clockwise direction, the value of the contour integral [latex]\oint _{C}\dfrac{dz}{z^{2}\left ( z-4 \right )}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\oint_{C} \frac{d z}{z^{2}(z-4)}[/latex] Singularities are given by [latex]z^{2}(z-4)=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad z=0,4[/latex] [latex] z=0[/latex] is pole of order [latex]m=2[/latex] lies inside contour 'c' [latex] z=4[/latex] is pole of order [latex]m=1[/latex] lies outside 'c' [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Res}_{0} &=\frac{1}{(2-1) !} \text{lt}_{\rightarrow 0} \frac{d^{2-1}}{d z^{2-1}}\left[(z-0)^{2} \frac{1}{z^{2}(z-4)}\right] \\ &=\frac{-1}{(0.4)^{2}}=\frac{-1}{16}\\ \text{By CRT}\\ \oint_{C} f(z) d z &=2 \pi j \text{Res}_{0}=2 \pi j\left[\frac{-1}{16}\right] \\ &=\frac{-j \pi }{8} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 In the circuit, switch 'S' is in the closed position for a very long time. If the switch is opened at time [latex]t = 0[/latex], then in [latex]i_{L} (t)[/latex] amperes, for [latex]t\geq0[/latex] is
solution: At [latex]t = 0^-[/latex] [latex] i_{L}\left(0^{-}\right)=\frac{10}{1}=10 \mathrm{~A}[/latex] For[latex] t > 0 [/latex] At [latex]t = \infty [/latex] [latex] i(\infty)=\frac{40}{5}=8 \mathrm{~A}[/latex] [latex] R_{\text{eq}}:[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{\mathrm{eq}} &=5 \Omega \\ \tau &=\frac{L}{R_{\mathrm{eq}}}=\frac{0.5}{5}=0.1 \mathrm{sec} \\ i(t) &=8+[10-8] e^{-t / 0.1} \\ &=8+2 e^{-10 t} \mathrm{~A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 The input impedance, [latex]Z_{in}\left ( s \right )[/latex] for the network shown is
solution: Circuit in s-domain, [latex]\begin{aligned} -S I_{1}+(4 s+5) I_{2} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \qquad I_{2} &=\frac{s}{4 s+5} I_{1} \\ V_{1} &=(4+6 s) I_{1}-\frac{s^{2}}{4 s+5} I_{1} \\ \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}} &=\frac{(4+6 s)(4 s+5)-s^{2}}{4 s+5} \\ &=\frac{24 s^{2}+30 s+16 s+20-s^{2}}{4 s+5} \\ Z_{\text {in }} &=\frac{23 s^{2}+46 s+20}{4 s+5} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The casual signal with z-transformer [latex]Z^{2}\left ( Z-a \right )^{-2}[/latex] is ([latex]u[n][/latex] is the unit step signal)
solution: As we know, [latex] \begin{aligned} n \cdot a^{n} u(n) & \rightleftharpoons \frac{a z}{(z-a)^{2}} \\ \frac{1}{a} \cdot n \cdot a^{n} u(n) & \rightleftharpoons \frac{z}{(z-a)^{2}} \\ f(n) &=n \cdot a^{n-1} u(n) \rightleftharpoons \frac{z}{(z-a)^{2}}=F(z) \end{aligned}[/latex] Time-shifting property, [latex] \begin{aligned} f(n) &\rightleftharpoons F(z) \\ f(n+1) &\rightleftharpoons z \cdot F(z) & \\ x(n)&=(n+1) a^{n} u(n+1) \rightleftharpoons \frac{z^{2}}{(z-a)^{2}}=X(z) & \\ \text{Thus},\qquad \qquad x(n)&=(n+1) a^{n} u(n+1)=(n+1) a^{n} \cdot u(n) \\ &[\because(n+1) u(n+1)=(n+1) u(n) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 Let [latex]f(t)[/latex] be an even function, i.e. [latex]f(-t)=f(t)[/latex] for all t. Let the Fourier transform of [latex]f(t)[/latex] be defined as [latex]F\left ( \omega \right )=\int\limits_{-\infty }^{\infty }\:f\left ( t \right )e^{-j\omega t}dt[/latex]. Suppose [latex]\dfrac{dF\left ( \omega \right )}{d\omega }=-\omega F\left ( \omega \right )[/latex] for all [latex]\omega[/latex], and [latex]F(0)=1[/latex]. Then
solution: [latex]f(t) \rightleftharpoons F(\omega)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) e^{-j \omega t} d t[/latex] The following informations are given about [latex]f(t) \rightleftharpoons F(\omega).[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} (i) f(t)=f(-t)\\ (ii) \left.F(\omega)\right|_{\omega=0}=1\\ (iii) \frac{d F(\omega)}{d \omega}=-\omega F(\omega)\\ \text{From }(iii), \frac{d F(\omega)}{d \omega}+\omega F(\omega)=0 \end{array}[/latex] By solving the above linear differential equations, (by mathematics) [latex] \begin{aligned} \ln F(\omega) &=-\frac{\omega^{2}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad F(\omega) &=K \cdot e^{-\omega^{2} / 2} \\ \text { Put } \omega=0, \qquad\qquad F(0) &=K \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad 1 &=K \text { (from info. } \\ \text { From (iv), } \qquad\qquad F(\omega) &=e^{-\omega^{2} / 2} \\ \text{As we know}, e^{-a t^{2}}, a \gt 0 &\rightleftharpoons \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} e^{-\omega^{2} / 4 a}\\ \text{At }a=\frac{1}{2}, \qquad\qquad\quad e^{-t^{2} / 2} &\rightleftharpoons \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{1 / 2}} \cdot e^{-\omega^{2} / 2}\\ f(t)&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-t^{2} / 2} \rightleftharpoons e^{-\omega^{2} / 2}=F(\omega)\\ \text { Thus, }\qquad\qquad f(t)&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-t^{2} / 2} \\ \text { At } t=0, \qquad\qquad f(0)&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \lt 1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 33 In a single-phase transformer, the total iron loss is [latex]2500\:W[/latex]
 at nominal voltage of [latex]440\:V[/latex] and frequency [latex]50\:Hz[/latex]. The total iron loss is [latex]850\:W[/latex] at [latex]220\:V[/latex] and [latex]25\:Hz[/latex]. Then, at nominal voltage and frequency, the hysteresis loss and eddy current loss respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_{i 1} &=2500 \mathrm{~W} \text { at } 440 \mathrm{~V}, 50 \mathrm{~Hz} \\ W_{i 2} &=850 \mathrm{~W} \text { at } 220 \mathrm{~V}, 25 \mathrm{~Hz} \\ W_{i 3} &=R_{e_{3}}+P_{H_{3}} \text { at } 440 \mathrm{~V}, 50 \mathrm{~Hz} \\ R_{\theta_{3}} &=?, \quad P_{h_{3}}=?, \quad \frac{v}{f}=\mathrm{constant} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad\quad 2500 &=A f+B f^{2} &\left\{\frac{400}{50}=\frac{220}{25}=\text { Constant }\right\} \\ \text { or, }\qquad \qquad \quad \frac{2500}{f} &=A+B f \\ \text{or},\qquad \qquad \frac{2500}{50}&=A+B(50) &\ldots(i)\\ \text{and}\qquad \qquad \frac{850}{25}&=\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B}(25)&\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving (i) and (ii), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 25 B &=\frac{2500}{50}-\frac{850}{25}=\frac{2500-1700}{50} \\ &=\frac{800}{50}=16 \\ B &=\frac{16}{25} \\ \text{and from (i)},\qquad A &=50-\frac{16}{25} \times 50=50-32=18\\ \text{So, at} 50 \mathrm{~Hz}\\ P_{h}&=A f=18 \times 50=900 \mathrm{~W} \\ P_{e}&=B f=\left(\frac{16}{25}\right) \times(50)^{2}=1600 \mathrm{~W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 In the figure shown, self-impedances of the two transmission lines are [latex]1.5j\:p.u[/latex] each, and [latex]Z_{m}=0.5j \:p.u[/latex] is the mutual impedance. Bus voltages shown in the figure are in p.u. Given that [latex]\delta>0[/latex], the maximum steady-state real power that can be transferred in p.u from Bus-1 to Bus-2 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{e q}&=\frac{L_{1} L_{2}-M^{2}}{\left(L_{1}+L_{2}-2 M\right)} \\ X_{\mathrm{eq}}&=\frac{1.5 \times 1.5-0.5^{2}}{1.5+1.5-2 \times 0.5}=1 \mathrm{p.u.} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{\max }&=\frac{|E||V|}{1}\\ P_{\max }&=|E||V| \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 A 3-Bus network is shown. Consider generators as ideal voltage sources. If rows [latex]1,\:2[/latex] and [latex]3[/latex] of the [latex]Y_{Bus}[/latex] matrix correspond to Bus [latex]1,\:2[/latex] and [latex]3[/latex], respectively, then [latex]Y_{Bus}[/latex] of the network is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{1} &=j 1 i_{1}+j 1\left(i_{1}+i_{2}+i_{3}\right) \\ V_{1} &=2 j i_{1}+j i_{2}+j i_{3} \\ \text{and}\qquad \qquad V_{2} &=j i_{1}+2 j i_{2}+j i_{3} \\ V_{3} &=j i_{1}+j i_{2}+2 j i_{3} \\ \therefore \qquad \left[\begin{array}{l} V_{1} \\ V_{2} \\ V_{3} \end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 j & j & j \\ j & 2 j & j \\ j & j & 2 j \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} i_{1} \\ i_{2} \\ i_{3} \end{array}\right]\\ Z_{\text {bus }}&=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 j & j & j \\ j & 2 j & j \\ j & j & 2 j \end{array}\right] \\ Y_{\text {bus }}&=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} \frac{-3 j}{4} & \frac{j}{4} & \frac{j}{4} \\ \frac{j}{4} & \frac{-3 j}{4} & \frac{j}{4} \\ \frac{j}{4} & \frac{j}{4} & \frac{-3 j}{4} \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: [latex]\begin{bmatrix} -4j & j & j\\ j& -4j & j\\ j& j & -4j \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question: Question 36 Suppose [latex]I_{A},\:I_{B}[/latex] and [latex]I_{C}[/latex] are a set of unbalanced current phasors in a three-phase system. The phase-B zero-sequence current [latex]I_{B0}=0.1\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex] p.u. If phase-A current [latex]I_{A}=1.1\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex] p.u and phase-C current [latex]I_{C}=\left ( 1\angle 120^{\circ}+0.1 \right )[/latex] p.u, then [latex]I_{B}[/latex] in p.u is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{B O} &=\frac{1}{3}\left(I_{A}+I_{B}+I_{C}\right) \\ 0.1 &=\frac{1}{3}\left(1.1 \angle 0+I_{B}+1 \angle 120^{\circ}+0.1\right) \\ I_{B} &=0.3-1.1 \angle 0-0.1-1 \angle 120^{\circ} \\ I_{B} &=-0.9-1 \angle 120^{\circ} \\ I_{B} &=0.1+1 \angle 240^{\circ} \\ I_{B} &=1 \angle-120^{\circ}+0.1 \angle 0^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

The input-output pairs are named [latex](D_{0},\:Q_{0}), (D_{1},\:Q_{1})[/latex] and [latex](D_{2},\:Q_{2})[/latex], where the subscript 0 denotes the least significant bit. The output sequence is desired to be the Gray-code sequence [latex]000, \:001, \:011,\: 010, \:110,\:111,\: 101[/latex] and [latex]100[/latex], repeating periodically. Note that the bits are listed in the [latex]Q_{2}\:Q_{1}\:Q_{0}[/latex] format. The combinational logic expression for [latex]D_{1}[/latex] is

Question 38 Let A be a [latex]10\times10[/latex] matrix such that [latex]A^{5}[/latex] is a null matrix, and let I be the [latex]10\times10[/latex] identity matrix. The determinant of [latex]\text{A+I}[/latex] is ___________________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given}:\qquad A^{5}&=0\\ A x &=\lambda x \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad A^{5} x &=\lambda^{5} x \quad(\because x \neq 0) \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \lambda^{5} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \lambda &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Eigen values of [latex]A+I[/latex] given [latex]\lambda+1[/latex] [latex] \because [/latex] Eigen values of [latex]I_{A}=1[/latex] Hence [latex]|A+I|=[/latex] Product of eigen values [latex]=1 \times 1 \times 1 \times \ldots 10 [/latex]times [latex] =1[/latex]

question: Question 39 A three-phase balanced voltage is applied to the load shown. The phase sequence is [latex]\text{RYB}[/latex]. The ratio [latex]\frac{\left | I_{B} \right |}{|I_{R}|}[/latex] is ____________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{R} &=\frac{V_{R B}}{-j 10}=\frac{V_{L} \angle-60^{\circ}}{-j 10}=\frac{V_{L}}{10} \angle 30^{\circ} \\ I_{Y} &=\frac{V_{Y B}}{j 10}=\frac{V_{L} \angle-120^{\circ}}{-j 10}=\frac{V_{L}}{10} \angle 150^{\circ} \\ \text { and }\qquad \qquad I_{B}&=-\left(I_{R}+I_{Y}\right)=\frac{V_{L}}{10} \angle-90^{\circ} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \left|\frac{I_{B}}{I_{R}}\right|&=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 In the given circuit, for maximum power to be delivered to [latex]R_{L}[/latex], its value should be ______________ [latex]\Omega[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]=\frac{-j}{\omega C}=\frac{-j}{1000 \times 0.5 \times 10^{-3}}=-j 2 \Omega[/latex] [latex] Z_{\text {in }}=2 \| j 2=\frac{j 4}{2+j 2}=\frac{j 2}{1+j 1}[/latex] For maximum power transfer, [latex] R_{L}=\left|Z_{\mathrm{TH}}\right|=\frac{2}{\sqrt{2}}=\sqrt{2}=1.414 \Omega[/latex]

question: Question 41 One coulomb of point charge moving with a uniform velocity [latex]10\:\hat{X} \text{m/s}[/latex] enters the region [latex]x\geq 0[/latex] having a magnetic flux density [latex]\overrightarrow{B}=\left ( 10y\:\hat{X} + 10x\:\hat{Y}+10\:\hat{Z}\right )T[/latex]. The magnitude of force on the charge at [latex]x=0^{+}[/latex] is _____________ N. ([latex]\hat{X}[/latex], [latex]\hat{Y}[/latex], and [latex]\hat{Z}[/latex] are unit vectors along x-axis, y-axis and z-axis, respectively.)
solution: Force on a charge moving with [latex]\vec{v}[/latex] velocity due to magnetic field is [latex] \begin{aligned} \vec{F} &=Q(\vec{v} \times \vec{B}) \\ &=1[10 \hat{x} \times(10 y \hat{x}+10 x \hat{y}+10 \hat{z}]\\ &=10(10 x) \hat{z}+10(10)(-\hat{y}) \\ &=100 x \hat{z}-100 \hat{y} \\ \left.\vec{F}\right|_{x=0^{+}} &=-100 \hat{y} \\ |\vec{F}| &=\sqrt{(-100)^{2}}=100 \text { Newton } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 Consider a large parallel plate capacitor. The gap 'd' between the two plates is filled entirely with a dielectric slab of relative permittivity 5. The plates are initially charged to a potential difference of V volts and then disconnected from the source. If the dielectric slab is pulled out completely, then the ratio of the new electric field [latex]E_{2}[/latex] in the gap to the original electric field [latex]E_{1}[/latex] is ________.
solution: If voltage source is removed then in both cases charge O is constant. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Case-1: }\left(Q_{1},=Q ; V_{1}=\right.&V) \\ Q_{1} &=C_{1} V_{1} \\ Q &=\frac{\epsilon_{0}(5) A}{d} V_{1} \\ Q &=5\left(\frac{\epsilon_{0} A}{d}\right) V_{1} \\ \text { Case-2: }\left(Q_{2}=Q ; V_{2}\right) & \\ Q_{2} &=C_{2} V_{2} \\ Q &=\frac{\epsilon_{0}(1) A}{d} V_{2} \\ Q &=\left(\frac{\epsilon_{0} A}{d}\right) V_{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Equation (i) is equal to equation (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow 5\left(\frac{\epsilon_{0} A}{d}\right) V_{1} &=\left(\frac{\epsilon_{0} A}{d}\right) V_{2} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 5 V_{1} &=V_{2} \\ \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} &=5 \\ E_{1} &=\frac{V_{1}}{d} ; E_{2}=\frac{V_{2}}{d} \\ \frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}} &=\frac{V_{2} / d}{V_{1} / d} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}} &=\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Put equation (iii) in equation (iv), [latex] \Rightarrow \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}}=5[/latex]

question: Question 43 Consider a continuous-time signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] defined by [latex]x(t)=0[/latex] for [latex]\left | t \right |> 1[/latex], and [latex]x\left ( t \right )=1-\left | t \right | for \left | t \right |\leq 1[/latex]. Let the Fourier transform of [latex]x(t)[/latex] be defined as [latex]X\left ( \omega \right )=\int\limits_{-\infty }^{\infty }\:x\left ( t \right )e^{-j\omega t}\:dt[/latex]. The maximum magnitude of [latex]X\left ( \omega \right )[/latex] is ___________.
solution: Fourier transform, [latex]F(\omega)=A \tau S a^{2}\left(\frac{\omega \tau}{2}\right) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { As } A=1, \tau=1 \\ H \omega) &=S a^{2}\left(\frac{\omega}{2}\right) \\ \left.F(\omega)\right|_{\text {peak }} &=F(0)=S a^{2}(0)=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \because [/latex] Peak value of sampling function occurs at [latex]\omega=0 [/latex] Peak value [latex]=1[/latex]

question:
Question 44 A belt-driven [latex]\text{DC}[/latex]
 shunt generator running at [latex]300\: \text{RPM}[/latex]
 delivers [latex]100 \:\text{kW}[/latex]
 to a [latex]200 \:V\: \text{DC}[/latex]
 grid. It continues to run as a motor when the belt breaks, taking [latex]10 \:\text{kW}[/latex]
 from the [latex]\text{DC}[/latex]
 grid. The armature resistance is [latex]0.025 \Omega[/latex], field resistance is [latex]50\:\Omega[/latex], and brush drop is [latex]2 \:V[/latex]. Ignoring armature reaction, the speed of the motor is _____  [latex]\text{RPM}[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{L} &=\frac{100 \times 10^{3}}{200}=500 \mathrm{~A} \\ I_{S h} &=\frac{200}{50}=4 \mathrm{~A} \\ I_{a} &=504 \mathrm{~A} \\ E_{q} &=V+I_{a} R_{a}+\text { Brush drop } \\ &=200+504(0.025)+2 \mathrm{~V} \\ &=214.6 \mathrm{~V}\\ \text{In motoring case:} V I&=10 \mathrm{~kW}, V=200 \mathrm{~V}\\ \therefore \qquad \qquad I &=\frac{10000}{200}=50 A \\ I_{f} &=4 \mathrm{~A}, I_{a}=I_{L}-I_{f} \\ &=46 \mathrm{~A} \\ E_{b} &=V-I_{a} R_{a}-\text { Brush Drop } \\ &=200-46(0.025)-2=196.85 \mathrm{~V} \\ \frac{N_{m}}{N_{g}} &=\frac{E_{b}}{E_{g}} \\ N_{m} &=\frac{E_{b}}{E_{g}} \times N_{g} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad N_{m} &=\frac{196.85}{214.6} \times 300=275.18 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 An 8-pole, [latex]50 \:Hz[/latex], three-phase, slip-ring induction motor has an effective rotor resistance of [latex]0.08\:\Omega[/latex] per phase. Its speed at maximum torque is [latex]650 \text{ RPM}[/latex]. The additional resistance per phase that must be inserted in the rotor to achieve maximum torque at start is _____________ [latex]\Omega[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.) Neglect magnetizing current and stator leakage impedance. Consider equivalent circuit parameters referred to stator.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_{\max } &=650 \mathrm{rpm}, P=8,50 \mathrm{~Hz} \\ s_{m} &=\frac{750-650}{750}=0.1333 \\ s_{m} &=\frac{R_{2}}{X_{2}} \\ \therefore\qquad \qquad X_{2} &=\frac{R_{2}}{s_{m}}=\frac{0.08}{0.133}=0.601 \Omega \\ R_{2} &=0.08 \Omega, X_{2}=0.601 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] Condition for maximum [latex]T_{\mathrm{s}}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad R_{2} & =X_{2} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad R_{2}+ R_{\text {ext }} & =X_{2} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad R_{\text {ext }} & =0.601-0.08=0.521 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 Consider a closed-loop system as shown. [latex]G_{P}\left ( s \right )=\dfrac{14.4}{s\left ( 1+0.1s \right )}[/latex] is the plant transfer function and [latex]G_{c}(S)=1[/latex] is the compensator. For a unit-step input, the output response has damped oscillations. The damped natural frequency is ___________________ [latex]\text{rad/s}[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} q(s)&=s^{2}+10 s+144=0 \\ \omega_{n}&=12 ; \xi=\frac{5}{12} \\ \omega_{d}&=\omega_{n} \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}} \\ \quad&=12 \sqrt{\frac{119}{144}}=10.90 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 In the given figure, plant [latex]G_{P}\left ( s \right )=\dfrac{2.2}{\left ( 1+0.1s \right )\left ( 1+0.4s \right )\left ( 1+1.2s \right )}[/latex] and compensator [latex]G_{C}\left ( s \right )=K\left [ \dfrac{1+T_{1}s}{1+T_{2}s} \right ][/latex]. The external disturbance input is D(s). It is desired that when the disturbance is a unit step, the steady-state error should not exceed 0.1 unit. The minimum value of K is _____________. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0}\left[\frac{s R}{1+G_{C} G_{p}}-\frac{s D G_{p}}{1+G_{C} G_{P}}\right] \\ R(s) &=0 ; D(s)=\frac{1}{s} \\ \therefore \qquad\qquad e_{s s}&=\frac{2.2}{1+2.2 K}=0.1 \\ \therefore \qquad\qquad K_{\min }&=9.54 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 The waveform shown in solid line is obtained by clipping a full-wave rectified sinusoid (shown dashed). The ratio of the [latex]\text{RMS}[/latex] value of the full-wave rectified waveform to the [latex]\text{RMS}[/latex] value of the clipped waveform is _______________. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: We know, RMS value of full wave rectified sine [latex]=\frac{V_{m}}{\sqrt{2}}=0.707 V_{m}[/latex] For clipped wave form As [latex]0 \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{4}[/latex] and [latex]\frac{3 \pi}{4} \rightarrow \pi[/latex] wave form are identical [latex] \begin{aligned} &\text { rms value of clipped wave } \\ &\left.=\sqrt{\frac{1}{\pi}\left[2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 4} V_{m}^{2} \sin ^{2} \omega t+\int_{\pi / 4}^{3 \pi / 4}\left(0.707 V_{m}\right)^{2} d \omega t\right.}\right] \\ &= \sqrt{\frac{1}{\pi}\left(\int_{0}^{\pi / 4} \frac{2 V_{m}^{2}}{2}[1-\cos 2 \omega t] d \omega t+\frac{1}{2} V_{m}^{2} \times \frac{\pi}{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}\\ &=\left[\frac{1}{\pi}\left[V_{m}^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \sin \frac{\pi}{2}\right)+\frac{V_{m}^{2}}{4} \pi\right]\right]^{1 / 2} \\ &=\left[\frac{V_{m}^{2}}{\pi}\left[\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2}\right]+\frac{V_{m}^{2}}{4}\right]^{1 / 2}=0.5838 V_{m} \\ \text { Ratio } &=\frac{0.707}{0.5838}=1.21 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 The state space representation of a first-order system is given as [latex]\overset{\bullet }{x}=-x+u[/latex] [latex]y=x[/latex] where,x is the state variable, u is the control input and y is the controlled output. Let [latex]u=-Kx[/latex] be the control law, where K is the controller gain. To place a closed-loop pole at -2, the value of K is ___________________.
solution: [latex]\dot{x}=-x-K x=x(-k I-I)[/latex] Characteristic equation, [latex] \begin{aligned} |S I+K I+I| &=0 \\ |(S+1+K) I| &=0 \\ \therefore \qquad\qquad S+1+K &=0 \\ S &=-1-K \\ -2 &=-1-K \\ K &=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 An air-core radio-frequency transformer as shown has a primary winding and a secondary winding. The mutual inductance M between the windings of the transformer is ____________ [latex]\mu H[/latex].(Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{1}&=\frac{5}{22}(p-p) \\ V_{0}&=j \omega M I_{1}=7.3=\left(2 \pi \times 10 \times 10^{3}\right) \times M \times\left(\frac{5}{22}\right) \\ M&=51.10 \mu \mathrm{H} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 A [latex]\text{100 Hz}[/latex] square wave, switching between [latex]\text{0 V}[/latex] and [latex]\text{5 V}[/latex], is applied to a [latex]\text{CR}[/latex] high-pass filter circuit as shown. The output voltage waveform across the resistor is [latex]\text{6.2 V}[/latex] peak-to-peak. If the resistance R is [latex]\text{820 $\Omega$}[/latex], then the value C is ______________[latex]\mu F[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{0}&=v_{i}-v_{c}\\ \text{For }1^{\text {st }}\text{ half cycle}, \quad v_{0}&=5-v_{c} \\ \text{For }2^{\text {nd }}\text{ half cycle}, \quad v_{0}&=-v_{c}\\ v_{p-p} &=\left(5-V_{c \;\min}\right)-\left(-V_{c}\; \max \right) \\ 6.2 &=5+V_{c \;\max }-V_{c \;\min} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{c \max }-V_{c \;\min } &=1.2 \ldots(\alpha) \end{aligned}[/latex] For first half cycle i.e. [latex]0 \lt t \lt \frac{T}{2}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{c}\left(0^{+}\right) &=v_{c}(0)=v_{c}\left(0^{-}\right)=v_{c} \min \\ v_{c}(\infty) &=5 \mathrm{~V} \\ \therefore \qquad\qquad v_{c}(t) &=v_{c}(\infty)+\left[v_{c}\left(0^{+}\right)-v_{c}(\infty)\right] e^{-t / \tau} \\ v_{c}(t) &=5+\left[V_{c m i n}-5\right] e^{-t / 2 \tau}=V_{c m a x} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad V_{c} \max &=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]+V_{c m i n} e^{-T / 2 \tau} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] For \frac{T}{2} \lt t \lt T[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{c}(t) &=v_{c}\left(\frac{T}{2}\right) e^{-t(t-T / 2) \tau} \\ \therefore\qquad v_{c}(t) &=V_{c m a x} e^{-(t-T / 2) \tau} \\ \text{at } t =T,\qquad \qquad v_{c} &=V_{c} \mathrm{~min} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad V_{C \mathrm{~min}} &=V_{C \max } e^{-T / 2 \tau}\\ \text { As } \quad V_{c \text { max }}-V_{c \text { min }}&=1.2 \qquad \qquad [\text { From }(\alpha)]\\ \therefore \quad V_{\text {cmax }}-V_{c \max } e^{-T / 2 t} &=1.2 \\ V_{c} \max &=\frac{1.2}{1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad V_{c} \max &=\frac{1.2}{1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}}=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]+V_{c \min } e^{-2 \tau} \end{aligned}[/latex] From (ii), [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{c \max } &=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]+\left(V_{c m a x} e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right) e^{-T / 2 \tau} \\ V_{c \max } &=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]+V_{c \max } e^{-T / \tau} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad V_{c \max }\left[1-e^{-T / \tau}\right] &=5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right] \\ V_{c} \max &=\frac{5\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]}{\left[1+e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]\left[1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}\right]} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using equation (iii) [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1.2}{1-e^{-T / 2 \tau}} &=\frac{5}{1+e^{-T / 2 \tau}} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 1.2+1.2 e^{-T / 2 \tau} &=5-5 e^{-\pi / 2 t} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 6.2 e^{-T / 2 \tau} &=3.8 \\ e^{-T / 2 \tau} &=\frac{3.8}{6.2}=0.6129 \\ \frac{T}{2 \tau} &=0.4895\\ \text { as }\qquad \qquad T&=\frac{1}{f}=\frac{1}{100} \mathrm{sec}\\ \text { and }\qquad \qquad \tau & =R C=820 \mathrm{C} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \frac{1}{(100)(2)(820) C} & =0.4895 \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad C & =12.46 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 A [latex]\text{CMOS}[/latex] Schmitt-trigger inverter has a low output level of [latex]\text{0 V}[/latex] and a high output level of [latex]\text{5 V}[/latex]. It has input thresholds of [latex]\text{1.6 V}[/latex] and [latex]\text{2.4 V}[/latex]. The input capacitance and output resistance of the Schmitt-trigger are negligible. The frequency of the oscillator shown is ____________[latex]\text{Hz}[/latex].(Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{c}(t)&=v_{c \text { final }}+\left[v_{\text {initial }}-v_{c^{\prime}} \text { final }\right] e^{- t / R C} \\ \text { Charging, } \qquad \qquad v_{c}(t)&=5+(1.6-5) e^{-t / R C}\\ &=5-3.4 e^{-t / R C}\\ t=t_{1}, \qquad \qquad v_{c}(t) &= 2.4 \mathrm{~V} \\ 2.4 &=5-3.4 e^{-t / \mathrm{RC}} \\ 3.4 e^{-11 / \mathrm{RC}} &= 2.6 \\ t_{1} &= \ln \left(\frac{3.4}{2.6}\right) R C=0.268 \times R C \end{aligned}[/latex] Discharging, [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{c}(t) &=0+(2.4-0) e^{-t / \mathrm{RC}} \\ &=2.4 e^{-t / \mathrm{RC}} \\ t=t_{2}, \qquad v_{c}\left(t_{a}\right) &=1.6 \mathrm{~V} \\ 1.6 &=2.4 e^{-12 / \mathrm{AC}} \\ t_{2} &=\ln \left(\frac{2.4}{1.6}\right) R C=0.405 \times R C \\ T &=t_{1}+t_{2}=(0.268+0.405) \mathrm{RC} \\ T &=0.673 \mathrm{RC} \\ f &=\frac{1}{0.673 R C}=\frac{1}{0.673 \times 10^{4} \times 47 \times 10^{-9}} \\ f &=3157.46 \mathrm{~Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 Consider the boost converter shown. Switch Q is operating at [latex]\text{25 kHz}[/latex] with a duty cycle of 0.6. Assume the diode and switch to be ideal. Under steady-state condition, the average resistance [latex]R_{\text{in}}[/latex] as seen by the source is __________ [latex]\Omega[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Checking for continuous conduction mode [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta I_{L} &=\frac{\alpha V_{S}}{f L}=\frac{0.6 \times 15}{25 \times 10^{3} \times 1 \times 10^{-3}}=0.36 \mathrm{~A} \\ \frac{\Delta I_{L}}{2} &=0.18 \mathrm{~A} \\ I_{L, \min } &=I_{L}-\frac{\Delta I_{L}}{2}=I_{S}-\frac{\Delta I_{L}}{2} \\ &=(9.375-0.18)=9.195>0 \end{aligned}[/latex] As it is continuous conduction [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{0}&=\frac{V_{S}}{1-\alpha}=\frac{15}{1-0.6}=37.5 \mathrm{~V} \\ I_{0}&=\frac{V_{0}}{R}=\frac{37.5}{10}=3.75 \mathrm{~V} \\ \frac{V_{0}}{V_{S}}&=\frac{I_{S}}{I_{0}}=\frac{1}{1-\alpha} \\ I_{S}&=\frac{I_{0}}{1-\alpha}=\frac{3.75}{1-0.6}=9.375 \mathrm{~A} \\ R_{\text {in }}&=\frac{V_{S}}{I_{S}}=\frac{15}{9.375}=1.6 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 Consider the buck-boost converter shown. Switch Q is operating at [latex]\text{25 kHz}[/latex] and 0.75 duty-cycle. Assume diode and switch to be ideal. Under steady-state condition, the average current flowing through the indicator is ____________A.
solution: [latex]\alpha=0.75, \quad f=25 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex] Assume continous conduction: [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{0}&=\frac{\alpha V_{s}}{1-\alpha}=\frac{0.75 \times 20}{1-0.75} \\ V_{0}&=60 \mathrm{~V}\\ I_{0} &=\frac{V_{0}}{R}=\frac{60}{10}=6 \mathrm{~A} \\ I_{L} &=\frac{I_{0}}{1-\alpha}=\frac{6}{1-0.75}=24 \mathrm{~A} \\ \Delta I_{L} &=\frac{\alpha V_{s}}{f_{L}}=\frac{0.75 \times 60}{25 \times 10^{3} \times\left(1 \times 10^{-3}\right)}=1.8 \mathrm{~A} \\ I_{L \min } &=I_{L}-\frac{\Delta I_{L}}{2}=24-\frac{1.8}{2}=24-0.9 \\ \left(I_{L \min }=23.1 \mathrm{~A}\right) &>0 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Continous conduction assumption is correct. [latex] I_{L}=24 \mathrm{~A}[/latex]

question: Question 55 A single-phase full-bridge inverter fed by a [latex]\text{325 V DC}[/latex] produces a symmetric quasi-square waveform across 'ab' as shown. To achieve a modulation index of 0.8, the angle [latex]\theta[/latex] expressed in degrees should be _______________. (Round off to 2 decimal places.) (Modulation index is defined as the ratio of the peak of the fundamental component of [latex]V_{ab}[/latex] to the applied [latex]\text{DC}[/latex] value.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \widehat{V_{01}} &=m_{a} V_{S}=0.8 \times 325=260 \mathrm{~V} \\ \widehat{V_{01}} &=\frac{4 V_{S}}{\pi} \sin d=260 \\ \frac{4(325)}{\pi} \sin d &=260 \\ \sin d &=\frac{260 \times \pi}{4 \times 325}=0.628 \\ d &=38.9 \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \theta &=\frac{\pi}{2}-d=90^{\circ}-38.9=51.1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 58 For a regular polygon having 10 sides, the interior angle between the sides of the polygon, in degrees, is:
solution: Sum of the interior angle [latex]=(n-2) \times 180=1440[/latex] The interior angle between two sides of polygon is [latex]\frac{1440}{10}=144.[/latex]

question: Question 59 Which one of the following numbers is exactly divisible by [latex]\left(11^{13}+1\right)[/latex]?
solution:
Consider expression [latex]\frac{x^{n}-a^{n}}{x+a}.[/latex] Now assuming similar expression [latex]11^{52}-1=\left(11^{13}\right)^{4}-(1)^{4}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\left(11^{13}\right)^{4}-(1)^{4}}{11^{3}+1} &=\frac{\left.\left((11)^{13}\right)^{2}-(1)^{2}\right)\left(\left(11^{13}\right)^{2}+(1)^{2}\right)}{11^{3}+1} \\
&=\left[\left(11^{13}-1\right)\right]\left[\left(11^{13}\right)^{2}+(1)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, [latex]11^{52}-1[/latex] is divisible by [latex]11^{13}+1.[/latex]

question: Question 60 Oasis is to sand as island is to _____________ Which one of the following options maintains a similar logical relation in the above sentence?
solution: Oasis is surrounded by sand as Island is surrounded by water

question: Question 61 The importance of sleep is often overlooked by students when they are preparing for exams. Research has consistently shown that sleep deprivation greatly reduces the ability to recall the material learnt. Hence, cutting down on sleep to study longer hours can be counterproductive. Which one of the following statements is the CORRECT inference from the above passage?
solution: First statement is ridiculous, third and fourth are contradictory to what is given in the passage.

options.A: Sleeping well alone is enough to prepare for an exam. Studying has lesser benefit.
options.B: Students are efficient and are not wrong in thinking that sleep is a waste of time.
options.C: If a student is extremely well prepared for an exam, he needs little or no sleep.
options.D: To do well in an exam, adequate sleep must be part of the preparation.

question: Question 62 In the figure shown above, each inside square is formed by joining the midpoints of the sides of the next larger square. The area of the smallest square (shaded) as shown, in [latex]\text{cm}^{2}[/latex] is:
solution: Side of outer first square [latex]=10 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex] Side of outer second [latex]=\frac{10}{\sqrt{2}} \mathrm{~cm}[/latex] like wise, Side of outer third square [latex]=\left(\frac{10}{(\sqrt{2})^{2}}\right)[/latex] Hence, side of smallest square [latex]=\frac{10}{(\sqrt{2})^{5}} [/latex] Area of smallest square [latex]=\left(\frac{10}{(\sqrt{2})^{5}}\right)^{2}=\frac{100}{2^{5}}=3.125[/latex]

question: Question 63 Let X be a continuous random variable denoting the temperature measured. The range of temperature is [latex][0,100][/latex] degree Celsius and let the probability density function of X be [latexf(x)=0.01[/latex] for [latex]0 \leq X \leq 100[/latex]. The mean of X is __________
solution: n is a continuous random variable for continuous random variable [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad f(x)&=\left\{\begin{array}{cc} \frac{1}{\beta-\alpha} & \alpha \leq x \leq \beta \\ 0 & \text { otherwise } \end{array}\right.\\ \text{From here},\qquad \alpha&=0, \beta=100 \end{aligned}[/latex] For continuous probability function mean [latex] =\frac{\alpha+\beta}{2}=\frac{0+100}{2}=50[/latex] Alternate Solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Given:}\qquad \text { pdf } f(x) &=10^{-2}, 0\lt x \lt 100 \\ E(x) &=\int_{0}^{100} x f(x) d x=\int_{0}^{100} x 10^{-2} d x \\ &\left.=\frac{1}{100} \frac{x^{2}}{2}\right]_{0}^{100}=\frac{100}{2}=50 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 64 The number of students passing or failing in an exam for a particular subject is presented in the bar chart above. Students who pass the exam cannot appear for the exam again. Students who fail the exam in the first attempt must appear for the exam in the following year. Students always pass the exam in their second attempt. The number of students who took the exam for the first time in the year 2 and the year 3 respectively, are ________.
solution: Total number of student in the year-2 [latex]= 60 + 5 = 65[/latex] Students who failed in the year and appeared in year-2 = 10 So the students who appeared first time in year-2 [latex]= 65 - 10 = 55[/latex] Similarly, Total number of students in year-3 = 53 Students who failed in the year-2 and appeared in year-3 = 5 So, the students who appeared first time in year-3 [latex] = 53 - 5 = 48[/latex]

T is parked to the left of U. Based on the above statements, the only INCORRECT option given below is:

options.A: There are two cars parked in between Q and V.
